video.title: Pygame Tutorial for Beginners - Python Game Development Course
video.description:
Learn how to use Pygame to code games with Python. In this full tutorial course, you will learn Pygame by building a space invaders game. The course will help you understand the main game development concepts like moving characters, shooting bullets, and more.

💻 Code: https://github.com/attreyabhatt/Space-Invaders-Pygame

🎥 Course created by buildwithpython. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCirPbvoHzD78Lnyll6YYUpg

⌨️ (0:00:00) Installing Python and Pycharm
⌨️ (0:04:12) Creating Our First Game Window
⌨️ (0:12:39) Changing the Title, Logo and Background Color
⌨️ (0:20:33) Adding Images into Our Space Invader Game
⌨️ (0:29:57) Movement Mechanics in Game Development
⌨️ (0:38:13) Keyboard Input Controls & Key Pressed Event
⌨️ (0:49:53) Adding Boundaries to Our Game
⌨️ (0:53:28) Creating the Enemy
⌨️ (0:59:14) Movement Mechanics of the Enemy Space Invader
⌨️ (1:06:51) Adding a Background Image
⌨️ (1:12:08) Creating Bullets for Shooting
⌨️ (1:26:21) Shooting Multiple Bullets at Space Invaders
⌨️ (1:34:24) Collision Detection
⌨️ (1:48:05) Creating Multiple Enemies
⌨️ (1:55:08) Adding Text and Displaying Score
⌨️ (2:03:17) Adding Sounds and Background Music
⌨️ (2:09:05) Game Over

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news

bulletY_change = 0.5
# ready means u cant see the bullet on the screen
# fire means the bullet can be seen on the screen and it y axis is constantly changing
bullet_state = "ready"

score = 0


def player(x, y):
    screen.blit(playerimg, (x, y))


def enemy(x, y):
    screen.blit(enemyimg, (x, y))


def fire_bullet(x, y):
    global bullet_state
    bullet_state = "fire"
    screen.blit(bulletimg, (x + -8, y + 10))


def fire_bullet2(x, y):
    global bullet_state
    bullet_state = "fire"
    screen.blit(bulletimg, (x + 40, y + 10))


def isCollision(enemyX, enemyY, bulletX, bulletY):
    distance = math.sqrt(math.pow(enemyX - bulletX, 2) + math.pow(enemyY - bulletY, 2))
    if distance < 24:
        return True
    else:
        return False


# game loop
is_running = True
while is_running:
    for event in pygame.event.get():
        if event.type == pygame.QUIT:
            is_running = False

        # keystrokes
        if event.type == pygame.KEYDOWN:
            if event.key == pygame.K_LEFT:
                playerX_change = -0.3
            if event.key == pygame.K_RIGHT:
                playerX_change = 0.3
            if event.key == pygame.K_SPACE:
                if bullet_state == "ready":
                    bulletX = playerX
                    fire_bullet(playerX, bulletY)
                    fire_bullet2(playerX, bulletY)
        if event.type == pygame.KEYUP:
            if event.key == pygame.K_LEFT or event.key == pygame.K_RIGHT:
                playerX_change = 0

    # checking for boundries for player
    playerX += playerX_change

    if playerX <= 0:
        playerX = 799
    if playerX >= 800:
        playerX = 0

    # checking for boundries for enemy
    enemyX += enemyX_change

    if enemyX <= 0:
        enemyX_change = 0.3
    if enemyX >= 736:
        enemyX_change = -0.3

    # bullet movement
    if bulletY <= 0:
        bulletY = 480
        bullet_state = "ready"
    if bullet_state == "fire":
        fire_bullet(bulletX, bulletY)
        bulletY -= bulletY_change

    if bullet_state == "fire":
        fire_bullet2(bulletX, bulletY)
        bulletY -= bulletY_change

    # Collison
    collision = isCollision(enemyX, enemyY, bulletX, bulletY)
    if collision:
        bulletY = 480
        bullet_state = "ready"
    score += 1
    print(score)

    player(playerX, playerY)
    enemy(enemyX, enemyY)
    enemyY += enemyY_change
    pygame.display.update()
    screen.fill((0, 200, 255))
    screen.blit(background, (0, 0))

replies.author: ForeverSleepy
replies.text: @Gitmonay Pygame is already pretty barebones, to be fair. You can write as much functionality as you want, since you don't have to use everything it provides. It doesn't really provide THAT much in the first place compared to an actual game engine. It's just a thin SDL wrapper. Most 2D libraries are like this that are based on software rendering, since the screen is just a bunch of pixels and pixel coordinates. Using the graphics hardware to write a 2D game is a bit more involved but you still end up with a bunch of coloured pixels at the end of the day.

topLevelComment.author: hossumquat
topLevelComment.text: The reason the alien sometimes scrolls quickly down the right side of the screen and disappears is because you set the alien's starting x to randint(0, 800).  This starting x is where the left edge of the alien will be drawn.  When checking if the aliens hits the edge of the screen, you check against 736 (I think).  So the alien could start beyond this 736, and if that is the case, it moves down and changes direction, but even though it moves in the left direction a small amount, it is still beyond the 736, so it moves down again and turns around to move right again, etc.  You should use randint(0, 736) to initialize the alien x starting position.

topLevelComment.author: hossumquat
topLevelComment.text: You made a common beginner mistake that is an excellent learning opportunity to teach about.  I'm talking about fire_bullet().  The mistake is not considering enough what this function's job is.  What exactly should it be doing?  It seems to have two purposes as you are using it, which is to initiate the firing of a single bullet, but also to render the bullet every frame.  It shouldn't be doing both of these things, because every frame, if a bullet is active, we are firing the bullet again every frame, since both purposes are served by this function.  The solution is to separate these two tasks into 2 functions, which is probably obvious if you really think about and understand what the tasks needing to be done are and the purposes of your functions well.  So add a render_bullet() function to handle drawing the bullet every frame, and have fire_bullet() only be called each time the fire key event occurs.  Even though the code works as it is, I still see this as a bug needing fixing, and often times errors like this lead to it breaking as the code evolves because one doesn't have a strong grasp of what the code should be doing.  Hopefully this advice helps someone just starting out learning all this programming.

# This is everything i have done so far.

import pygame
import random

# CTRL + ALT + L FORMATS CODE TO LOOK GOOD ON SCREEN.

# Initialize the pygame.
pygame.init()

# Create the screen size. Width/Height.
screen = pygame.display.set_mode((800, 600))

# Background image
background = pygame.image.load("space-background.jpg")

# Title and logo
pygame.display.set_caption("Space Invaders")
icon = pygame.image.load('ufo.png')
pygame.display.set_icon(icon)

# Player location on screen.
playerImg = pygame.image.load('space-invaders.png')
playerX = 370
playerY = 480
playerX_change = 0

# Enemy location on screen.
# random.randint tells the enemy to spawn in random areas of the screen.
enemyImg = pygame.image.load('enemy.png')
enemyX = random.randint(0, 800)
enemyY = random.randint(50, 150)
enemyX_change = 0.3
enemyY_change = 40

# Bullet
# Ready state - You cant see the bullet on the screen.
# Fire - The bullet is currently moving
bulletImg = pygame.image.load('bullet.png')
bulletX = 0
bulletY = 480
bulletX_change = 0
bulletY_change = 10
bullet_state = "ready"


# .blit means to draw.
def player(x, y):
    screen.blit(playerImg, (x, y))


def enemy(x, y):
    screen.blit(enemyImg, (x, y))


# screen.blit determines that the bullet is fired from the top center of the ship.
def fire_bullet(x, y):
    global bullet_state
    bullet_state = "fire"
    screen.blit(bulletImg, (x + 16, y + 10))


# GAME LOOP
# Window will run indefinitely until exit button is pressed.
running = True
while running:

    # RGB = red, green, blue. used to determine colour.
    # Screen.fill needs to be at the top, as everything will be placed on top of it.
    screen.fill((0, 0, 0))
    # Background image
    screen.blit(background, (0, 0))

    for event in pygame.event.get():
        if event.type == pygame.QUIT:
            running = False

    # If keystroke is pressed check whether is right or left.
    # If left stoke is pressed increase the value by 0.3.
    # If right stroke is pressed decrease the value by 0.3.
    # playerX_change = 0 tells the ship to stop if button is released.

    if event.type == pygame.KEYDOWN:

        if event.key == pygame.K_LEFT:
            playerX_change = -0.3
        if event.key == pygame.K_RIGHT:
            playerX_change = 0.3
        if event.key == pygame.K_SPACE:
            fire_bullet(playerX, bulletY)

    if event.type == pygame.KEYUP:
        if event.key == pygame.K_LEFT or event.key == pygame.K_RIGHT:
            playerX_change = 0

    # Player appear on top of screen.
    playerX += playerX_change

    # if statement below prevents player from moving off the screen.
    if playerX <= 0:
        playerX = 0
    elif playerX >= 736:
        playerX = 736

    # Enemy movement.
    enemyX += enemyX_change

    if enemyX <= 0:
        enemyX_change = 0.2
        enemyY += enemyY_change
    elif enemyX >= 736:
        enemyX_change = -0.2
        enemyY += enemyY_change

    # Bullet movement.
    if bullet_state is "fire":
        fire_bullet(playerX, bulletY)
        bulletY -= bulletY_change

    player(playerX, playerY)
    enemy(enemyX, enemyY)

    pygame.display.update()

    # Used to update screen display.
    pygame.display.update()

For collision detection pygame actually has a method called 'colliderect' which detects collision between rectangles. So, if you want to check if the enemy rectangle has collided with the bullet rectangle, instead of checking the distance between the two for every frame, you just write:
if enemy_rectangle.colliderect(bullet_rectangle)
    [whatever you want to do when the enemy collides with a bullet, or vice versa]

replies.author: Bergen GobleLidstone
replies.text:
Ok, Here is what I did to solve this problem. (This is for Windows)

1.) Open up two file windows.

2.)  Download the PNG you want to use,  use one of the windows to go to "quick access" to see where its been originally downloaded.

3.) On the SECOND window, go to click on "This PC", then "Windows (C:)", then "Users, then click on the user where the Pycharm game is located, then "Pycharm Projects", then Click on what you named this project (If you followed to the word its called "Space Invaders"), now you will be in the file where all of the Python and Pycharm files are located for this game.

4.) Restore down (Click the middle button between the "X" out and the minimize on the top right) both windows so you can see both the quick access, and the "Space Invaders" file.

5.)Drag the PNG you want to use as the icon for your game into the "Space Invaders" file.

6.) Check if the PNG is now in your Pycharm files by going onto Pycharm and looking at the project files.

7.) Do as the tutorial says at 14:57 to make that PNG your icon.

PS. To find where you have any file go onto Pycharm, go onto Pycharm, then look at the project folders on the left, then near the name of what you called your project there should be a thing that says something like C:\User\name_of_user\PycharmProjects\name_of_pycharm_project which is where that project, and the project files are being stored.

I hope you found this Helpful,

- Random Canadian 2712

Quick tip.  If anyone keeps their .png files for icons and whatnot in a separate folder, within their python folder, then simply calling it wont work.  I used a shield as my icon.  
At the top, under "import pygame" you'll have to add "import os"
Then replace the line:
icon = pygame.image.load ('shield.png')
with the line:
icon = pygame.image.load(os.path.join("assets", "shield.png"))

The folder I keep my icons in is named "assets" and my icon was a shield, so just replace those two things with whatever you have.


I hope this helps someone, im very new to python but I picked up on that pretty early on :)

topLevelComment.author: Absurd 72
topLevelComment.text:
here is the code for snake game( You just nee to install pygame)

import pygame
import time
import random
pygame.init()
white = (255, 255, 255)
yellow = (255, 255, 102)
black = (0, 0, 0)
red = (213, 50, 80)
green = (0, 255, 0)
blue = (50, 153, 213)
dis_width = 600
dis_height = 400
dis = pygame.display.set_mode((dis_width, dis_height))
pygame.display.set_caption('Snake Game by Edureka')
clock = pygame.time.Clock()
snake_block = 10
snake_speed = 15
font_style = pygame.font.SysFont("bahnschrift", 25)
score_font = pygame.font.SysFont("comicsansms", 35)

def Your_score(score):
    value = score_font.render("Your Score: " + str(score), True, yellow)
    dis.blit(value, [0, 0])

def our_snake(snake_block, snake_list):
    for x in snake_list:
        pygame.draw.rect(dis, black, [x[0], x[1], snake_block, snake_block])

def message(msg, color):
    mesg = font_style.render(msg, True, color)
    dis.blit(mesg, [dis_width / 6, dis_height / 3])

def gameLoop():
    game_over = False
    game_close = False
    x1 = dis_width / 2
    y1 = dis_height / 2
    x1_change = 0
    y1_change = 0
    snake_List = []
    Length_of_snake = 1
    foodx = round(random.randrange(0, dis_width - snake_block) / 10.0) * 10.0
    foody = round(random.randrange(0, dis_height - snake_block) / 10.0) * 10.0
    while not game_over:
        while game_close == True:
            dis.fill(blue)
            message("You Lost! Press C-Play Again or Q-Quit", red)
            Your_score(Length_of_snake - 1)
            pygame.display.update()
            for event in pygame.event.get():
                if event.type == pygame.KEYDOWN:
                    if event.key == pygame.K_q:
                        game_over = True
                        game_close = False
                    if event.key == pygame.K_c:
                        gameLoop()
        for event in pygame.event.get():
            if event.type == pygame.QUIT:
                game_over = True
            if event.type == pygame.KEYDOWN:
                if event.key == pygame.K_LEFT:
                    x1_change = -snake_block
                    y1_change = 0
                elif event.key == pygame.K_RIGHT:
                    x1_change = snake_block
                    y1_change = 0
                elif event.key == pygame.K_UP:
                    y1_change = -snake_block
                    x1_change = 0
                elif event.key == pygame.K_DOWN:
                    y1_change = snake_block
                    x1_change = 0
        if x1 >= dis_width or x1 < 0 or y1 >= dis_height or y1 < 0:
            game_close = True
        x1 += x1_change
        y1 += y1_change
        dis.fill(blue)
        pygame.draw.rect(dis, green, [foodx, foody, snake_block, snake_block])
        snake_Head = []
        snake_Head.append(x1)
        snake_Head.append(y1)
        snake_List.append(snake_Head)
        if len(snake_List) > Length_of_snake:
            del snake_List[0]
        for x in snake_List[:-1]:
            if x == snake_Head:
                game_close = True
        our_snake(snake_block, snake_List)
        Your_score(Length_of_snake - 1)
        pygame.display.update()
        if x1 == foodx and y1 == foody:
            foodx = round(random.randrange(0, dis_width - snake_block) / 10.0) * 10.0
            foody = round(random.randrange(0, dis_height - snake_block) / 10.0) * 10.0
            Length_of_snake += 1
        clock.tick(snake_speed)
    pygame.quit()
    quit()
gameLoop()

replies.author: gtapanda 129
replies.text:
If you're talking about "event.type", it's exactly what it looks like, an event type. Type of event. When you say
"if event.type == pygame.KEYUP:
     doSomething()"
you are saying "if the type of event that's happening is a key being released, do a thing."
The "type()" function returns what type (as in int, str, boolean, list, dict, etc...) that the parameter(s) was/were. So not quite the same, but pretty similar.

replies.author: Vladimir Ogre
replies.text:
Incorprate delta time and use it to multiply the movement speeds,
clock = pygame.time.Clock()
while run:
    timedelta = clock.tick(60)
    timedelta /= 1000
    speed = (64 * timedelta)

Now the object you move with speed will move 64 x/y per second and fps will be 60.

import pygame
import random

# Initilise pygame
pygame.init()

# Create the screen
screen = pygame.display.set_mode((800, 600))

# Title
pygame.display.set_caption("Space Invaders")
icon = pygame.image.load('spaceship.png')
pygame.display.set_icon(icon)

# player
playerImg = pygame.image.load('space-invaders.png')
playerX = 370
playerY = 480
playerX_change = 0

# Enemy
enemyImg = pygame.image.load('invaders.png')
enemyX = random.randint(0, 800)
enemyY = random.randint(50, 150)
enemyX_change = 0.2
enemyY_change = 40


def player(x, y):
    screen.blit(playerImg, (x, y))


def enemy(x,y):
    screen.blit(enemyImg, (x, y))


# Game loop
running = True
while running:
    screen.fill((0, 0, 0))

    for event in pygame.event.get():
        if event.type == pygame.QUIT:
            running = False

        if event.type == pygame.KEYDOWN:
            if event.key == pygame.K_LEFT:
                playerX_change = -0.3
            if event.key == pygame.K_RIGHT:
                playerX_change = 0.3
        if event.type == pygame.KEYUP:
            if event.key == pygame.K_LEFT or event.key == pygame.K_RIGHT:
                playerX_change = 0

    playerX += playerX_change

    if playerX <= 0:
        playerX = 0
    elif playerX >= 736:
        playerX = 736

    enemyX += enemyX_change

    if enemyX <= 0:
        enemyY_change += enemyY_change
        enemyX_change = 0.2
    elif enemyX >= 736:
        enemyY_change += enemyY_change
        enemyX_change = -0.2

    player(playerX, playerY)
    enemy(enemyX, enemyY)
    pygame.display.update()

topLevelComment.author: Mihnea
topLevelComment.text: Question. When the player moves left and right, I tried some alternative code that trys to adjust the playerX and playerY coordinate directly. It does not work. Why is this? Why does it work when we have this temporary playerX_change variable?

replies.author: Mihnea
replies.text: AHHH I get it. If you hold the left or right arrow key down without releasing it, it is not recognized by the engine as a many separate KEYDOWN events, just one. So basically even if you hold down the left arrow key for eternity the engine see's it as only one keydown event. So the reason we can keep moving in some direction when the key is down is because, when the KEYDOWN event is first registered, playerX_change is set to a constant non zero value that alters the x position of our player indefinitely on each iteration, until this constant is set to 0(releasing the key and the engine recognizes a KEYUP event), which then keeps our player in the same spot when it is added to playerX.
